header.title: ATER VOTUM: A Book of Daemonolatry Prayer
header.category: Daemonolatry, Theistic Satanism, Prayer Book, Occultism

central_thesis: This book serves as a devotional and philosophical guide for Daemonolaters and Theistic Satanists, offering a collection of prayers and scriptures to facilitate invocation, foster a deeper connection with specific daemonic entities and the 'Demonic Divine' (Satan as the All of Creation), and provide a non-Abrahamic, Hermetically-influenced framework for spiritual growth, self-knowledge, and understanding natural laws.

structure_content.summary: Invokes Lucifer for wisdom and material stability, Belial for tangible world stability, and Belphegore for financial opportunity and victory, aiming for comfortable dwelling and necessities in the physical realm.

structure_content.chapter_title: Prayer for Victory in Legal Disputes or Judgments in Your Favor
structure_content.summary: Addresses Lord Leviathan to bring favorable judgment, success, and mercy in legal disputes, ensuring opponents do not hinder progress.
Invokes Tezrian, Sonnelion, Unsere, and Lilith to grant emotional strength, overcome obstacles, and empower the practitioner as a creator and sorceress.
A prayer to Verrine, personifying life, green, and health, requesting her presence and healing power among followers.

A blood offering to Lord Belphegore expressing respect and devotion, seeking blessings, divine power, and abundance for the practitioner and loved ones, also invoking Belial, Baal, Balberith, and other Earth Daemons.
Honors Lord Lucifer as the bringer of light from darkness, the source of enlightenment, wisdom, and lessons for life's journey.
A vow of everlasting devotion to Lord Satan, seeking safety, internal strength, and resolve under his name.

A sequence of prayers including a 'Daemonic Creed' (belief in Satan as the 'Ether of All', Lucifer as 'Enlightenment'), 'The Infernal Father' (Satan for wisdom, enlightenment, truth), 'The Third Prayer' (Glory to Satan, mercy via Unsere, temperance via Amducious), 'The Hail Elementals' (invoking Belial for earth, Lucifer for air, Flereous for fire, Leviathan for water), 'The Fifth Prayer' (Satan for connection to Daemonic Divine via Lucifuge Rofocale, Verrine, Amducious), 'The Balance of Life & Death' (Unsere for creation, Eurynomous for dead, sacred balance), 'Let Us Pray' (Satan for balance, eternal cycle of life, self-knowledge through Nine Divinities), 'Satan's Prayer' (worship for infernal wisdom), and 'The Ninth Prayer' (protection, enlightenment, abundance, and peace from Infernal Divinities).
Invokes Unsere for understanding, Lucifer for wisdom, and various Demons for peace across the earth, in homes, and for a new generation rooted in love and understanding.
Calls upon Amducius, Amon, Mammon, and Abaddon to protect soldiers, grant them strength, resolve, guidance on battlefields, and safe return.

structure_content.chapter_title: Prayer for Loved Ones Far Away
structure_content.summary: Beseeches Lord Satan to bless and protect loved ones who are distant, granting them wisdom, safety, happiness, and enjoyment of life.
Prays to Our Lady Unsere for wisdom, patience, and fortitude for mothers in guiding their children and families, acknowledging them as bringers of life.
Prays to Our Father Satan for wisdom, strength, and patience for fathers in guiding their children, recognizing their role in protection and sustenance.
Asks Unsere to protect and keep children, allowing them to grow into functional members of society, and Lucifer to grant them wisdom and the ability to partake in life's offerings.
Expresses gratitude to the Demons of Earth (Belial, Behemot, Belphegore, Baal) for the bounty, sustenance, and nourishment that sustains life.
A personal prayer of gratitude to Lord Lucifer for teaching truth, strength, and wisdom, for being present in times of need, and for illuminating the path to enlightenment.
A philosophical poem exploring self-knowledge, inner strength, overcoming fears, and divine guidance from Satan, emphasizing personal understanding over external sources.
A poetic invocation of Mammon, Belphegore, Belial, Ashtaroth, and Verrine for material wealth (silver, gold, diamonds), beauty (roses), friendships, and physical health/well-being.

Poetic invocations of Lucifer (hope, joy, vigor, light), Flereous (eagerness, fire, skill), Leviathan (kindness, grace, welcoming waters, blessings), and Belial (gentleness, pleasure, earthy presence, wealth) for elemental blessings throughout the day.
A personal and devotional prayer to Father Satan, expressing deep worship and praise for revealing true strength, love, and light from darkness.

structure_content.chapter_title: Tasa Satanachia: A Prayer (by lianna diabolique)
structure_content.summary: An intense ritualistic prayer invoking Satanachia for unleashing fire, lust, and desire; for spiritual possession, opening the third eye, and dissolving the self. It includes repetitive calls and declarations of devotion, culminating in an embrace of the 'Black Soul' and being 'Born of the dragon, Harlot, with Unholy Spirit'.

A collection of ancient Egyptian proverbs, modified for Daemonolaters and Theistic Satanists, emphasizing self-knowledge ('Man know thyself'), the immanence of the 'infernal kingdom' within, the pursuit of truth through nature, the importance of inner light and concentration, and the role of 'Satan' (formerly Maat) in natural order and justice.

Presented as a foundational (though disputed) scripture for modern theistic Satanists and Daemonolaters, where the 'I' is interpreted as Satan referring to Himself. It discusses Satan's eternal dominion, omnipresence, control over all affairs, guidance of followers, and the alteration of other religious texts. It outlines principles of reward, punishment, transmigration of souls, and divine guidance without revealed books.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Demonolatry and Literary Perspective of the Al-Jilwah (By S. Connolly)
structure_content.summary: An essay interpreting the Al-Jilwah from a Daemonolater's perspective, suggesting 'Satan' represents the 'All of Creation' or universal consciousness, aligning with Hermetic principles of balance and natural law rather than an Abrahamic 'God'. It views demons as 'servants' or 'Demonic Divine' teaching natural laws, and emphasizes experiential wisdom over written texts, while also advocating for separating from Abrahamic religious conflict.

key_concepts.definition: A system of religious belief and practice centered on the worship, reverence, and invocation of daemonic entities, viewed as aspects of the divine or 'Demonic Divine', rather than inherently evil.

The worship or reverence of Satan as a literal deity, distinct from symbolic or atheistic Satanism. In this context, Satan is often synonymous with the 'All of Creation' or the ultimate universal force.

The ultimate universal principle, described as the 'Ether of All the Is,' 'Creator of the universe and the spirit that binds the All together,' and a natural part of the universe. Satan is presented as a source of wisdom, enlightenment, and natural laws, rather than an adversary in an Abrahamic sense.
Referred to as the 'Enlightenment of Satan,' he represents the bringer of light from darkness, wisdom, and a guide to enlightenment and understanding of lessons.
A Daemoness of Blessings, whose name alone is considered potent enough to confer blessings. Often used as an alternative ending to prayers for Daemonolaters.

Translated as 'So be it' (Hebrew) or referencing the 'hidden aspect (and highest power) of Amen Ra' in ancient Egypt. In this context, it is used to direct prayers to the highest aspect of deity, with the option for Daemonolaters to substitute 'Satan,' 'Naamah,' or 'Lucifer.'

A disputed Yezidi scripture reinterpreted as Satanic literature. It serves as a metaphorical text for Daemonolaters, conveying messages of universal consciousness, balance, natural laws, and self-empowerment through the lens of the 'I' as Satan.

An esoteric philosophical tradition implicitly referenced as a foundation for Daemonolatry. Principles like polarity, self-knowledge ('Man know thyself'), and the divine immanence within nature are integrated, particularly in the interpretation of the Al-Jilwah and the Proverbs.

Specific daemonic entities associated with elements (Belial-earth, Lucifer-air, Flereous-fire, Leviathan-water), life/death (Unsere, Eurynomous), and various aspects of human experience (e.g., Verrine-healing, Amducious-temperance). They are invoked for distinct practical and spiritual purposes.

A central theme emphasizing that true wisdom, strength, and enlightenment are cultivated from within, through introspection, experience, and understanding one's own nature and connection to the Demonic Divine.

The inherent principles governing the universe and life, which 'Satan' embodies. Adherence to these laws leads to growth and harmony, while opposing them results in negative consequences for oneself and the universal balance.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in 'ATER VOTUM' is primarily prayer-based, focusing on direct invocation and devotional practice toward a pantheon of daemonic entities, with 'Satan' understood as the overarching 'All of Creation' or Demonic Divine. The system is operative in addressing various life aspects—such as financial security, emotional resilience, healing, legal outcomes, protection, and peace—by invoking specific Daemons whose natures align with these needs. It emphasizes personal connection, understanding the inherent natural laws of the universe, and a non-Abrahamic interpretation of daemonic forces, where these entities serve as guides, sources of strength, wisdom, and aid.
tools: The 'Al-Jilwah' text itself, utilized for meditation, study, and reinterpretation within a Daemonolatric framework.
Offerings, specifically 'blood offering' mentioned for Belphegore, suggesting ritualistic components beyond purely mental or verbal engagement.
Incense or herbs for smoking during specific invocations to facilitate altered states of consciousness or to 'come under a spell' (as mentioned in 'Tasa Satanachia').
Personal intent, will, and devotion, which are fundamental to the efficacy of the prayers and invocations.
rituals: Direct invocation and prayer to specific Daemons (e.g., Lucifer for wisdom, Belial for stability, Belphegore for finance, Leviathan for legal matters, Verrine for healing, Unsere for maternal guidance/peace, Satan for protection/strength, Amducius for soldiers).
Blood offerings as an act of profound respect and devotion (e.g., for Belphegore, implying a structured ritual beyond mere verbal prayer).
Recitation of formalized creeds and prayers (e.g., 'The Daemonic Creed,' 'The Infernal Father,' 'Nine Prayers') to affirm belief and commitment.
Personal reflection, thanksgiving, and vows of devotion.
Chanting and magical calls, such as 'Tasa reme laris Satan' and 'Zazas, Zazas, Nasatanda Zazas!!!!!!', particularly in more intense invocations for spiritual possession or transformation.

relevant_quotes.text: ATER VOTUM A Book of Daemonolatry Prayer

Please Note: Amen is used in prayers herein. Amen, meaning 'So be it' in Hebrew, has even earlier origins in prayer. In ancient Egypt Amen was the hidden aspect (and highest power) of Amen Ra. To send the prayer to the highest, most hidden aspect of deity, Amen was said at the end of prayer. For Satanists and Daemonolaters, you may end your prayer with Satan, Naamah, Lucifer, or simply Amen. It's really up to you.

The Daemonic Creed: I believe in Satan, the Ether of All the Is, Creator of the universe and the spirit that binds the All together. I believe in and give my allegiance to Lucifer, the Enlightenment of Satan, who was conceived by Unsere in compassion and understanding of all things. I give myself to the infernal flames of Baphometic Fire that I am reborn as the Phoenix in Satan's name. Amen.
The body is the house of God [the Demonic Divine]. That is why it is said, 'Man know thyself.'
Maat [Satan], who links universal to terrestrial, the divine with the human is incomprehensible to the cerebral intelligence.
Man, know thyself ... and thou shalt know the gods.
The Al-Jilwah is the disputed (among many Satanists) scripture of many modern theistic Satanists... Please note that the *I* in this text, is viewed as Satan referring to Himself.
The first chapter is not the description of a 'God' necessarily. Instead, it describes the All of Creation. The Ether of All that Is, He that we Satanists and Demonolaters call, Satan.
This entire chapter simply defines the nature of Satan as a natural part of the universe.
The servants are the Demons from my perspective. The Demonic Divine who teach the wisdom of Satan's natural laws and guide us through our physical lives and on to the next plane of existence.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant for practitioners of Daemonolatry and Theistic Satanism, serving as both a practical devotional guide and a philosophical text. It provides a structured collection of prayers for a wide array of personal and interpersonal needs, establishing a clear framework for interaction with specific daemonic entities. Its inclusion and reinterpretation of the Al-Jilwah, coupled with the contextualization through ancient Egyptian proverbs and modern commentary, significantly contributes to the philosophical underpinnings of modern Daemonolatry. It presents 'Satan' not as an Abrahamic evil, but as the 'All of Creation,' integrating Hermetic and polytheistic concepts. This approach offers a robust, non-dogmatic path to spiritual enlightenment, self-discovery, and understanding one's place within universal natural laws.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of Daemonolaters and Theistic Satanists, as explicitly stated. More broadly, it appeals to practitioners of Western Esotericism and Occultism who are exploring infernal currents, daemonic pantheons, and non-Abrahamic spiritual frameworks. It is particularly beneficial for those seeking formalized devotional practices, structured invocations, and a philosophical grounding that defines daemonic forces as integral to the cosmic order rather than adversarial. The commentary on the Al-Jilwah also makes it relevant for those interested in syncretic interpretations of ancient texts within modern occult practices.
